hints_html:
Use the coordinate planes and the equations \(\displaystyle y=1-x\) and \(\displaystyle z=y^2\) to find the integration limits

\(\displaystyle z \in [0, y^2]\)

\(\displaystyle y \in [0, 1-x]\)

\(\displaystyle x \in [0,1]\)

Remember to integrate first with respect to depending variable(s), and later with the independent variable(s).

Hence, the integral to calculate is

\(\displaystyle \int_0^1\int_0^{1-x}\int_0^{y^2}z\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x\)
hints_latex:
Use the coordinate planes and the equations $\displaystyle y=1-x$ and
$\displaystyle z=y^2$ to find the integration limits

$\displaystyle z \in [0, y^2]$

$\displaystyle y \in [0, 1-x]$

$\displaystyle x \in [0,1]$

Remember to integrate first with respect to depending variable(s), and
later with the independent variable(s).

Hence, the integral to calculate is

$\displaystyle \int_0^1\int_0^{1-x}\int_0^{y^2}z\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x$
hints_raw:
Use the coordinate planes and the equations <math>\displaystyle y=1-x</math> and <math>\displaystyle z=y^2</math> to find the integration limits


<math>\displaystyle z \in [0, y^2]</math>


<math>\displaystyle y \in [0, 1-x]</math>



<math>\displaystyle x \in [0,1] </math>
Remember to integrate first with respect to depending variable(s), and later with the independent variable(s).

Hence, the integral to calculate is

<math>\displaystyle \int_0^1\int_0^{1-x}\int_0^{y^2}z\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{d}x</math>
sols_html:
We find that the integration boundaries are \(\displaystyle z\in[0,y^2],\ \ y\in[0,1-x],\ \ x\in[0,1]\)

Hence, the integral to calculate is

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1\int_0^{1-x}\int_0^{y^2}z\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{x} &= \int_0^1\int_{0}^{1-x}\left[\frac{z^2}{2}\right]_0^{y^2}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\ &=\int_0^1\int_{0}^{1-x}\frac{y^4}{2}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\ &=\int_0^1\left[\frac{y^5}{10}\right]_0^{1-x}\;\text{d}x\\ &=\int_0^1\frac{(1-x)^5}{10}\;\text{d}x\\ &= \left[-\frac{(1-x)^6}{60}\right]_0^1\\ &= \frac{1}{60}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We find that the integration boundaries are <math>\displaystyle z\in[0,y^2],\ \ y\in[0,1-x],\ \ x\in[0,1]</math>


Hence, the integral to calculate is


<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
 \int_0^1\int_0^{1-x}\int_0^{y^2}z\;\text{d}z\text{d}y\text{x} 
&= \int_0^1\int_{0}^{1-x}\left[\frac{z^2}{2}\right]_0^{y^2}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&=\int_0^1\int_{0}^{1-x}\frac{y^4}{2}\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&=\int_0^1\left[\frac{y^5}{10}\right]_0^{1-x}\;\text{d}x\\
&=\int_0^1\frac{(1-x)^5}{10}\;\text{d}x\\
&= \left[-\frac{(1-x)^6}{60}\right]_0^1\\
&= \frac{1}{60}
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Let E be the region in the first octant bounded by the coordinate planes, the plane

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x+y=1,\end{aligned}\]

and the surface

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}z=y^2.\end{aligned}\]

Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \iiint\limits_{E}z\textrm{d}V.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Let E be the region in the first octant bounded by the coordinate planes, the plane

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x+y=1,
</math>

and the surface

:<math>
\displaystyle{}z=y^2.
</math>

Evaluate

:<math>
\iiint\limits_{E}z\textrm{d}V.
</math>
